![Author_img](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

Everyone wants to “add AI” to their product stack. But peel back the layers and you’ll find the same story in most organizations: fragmented datasets, undocumented pipelines, missing context, and noisy warehouses that struggle with even basic reporting.

It shows up in numbers too.

And this is exactly what our Principal Architect, **Ratnesh Parihar**, has been calling out in his deep-dive webinar *“*[*Is Your Data Ready for AI? Common Pitfalls and Practical Solutions.*](https://www.talentica.com/webinars/is-your-data-ready-for-ai-common-pitfalls-and-practical-solutions/)*”*

**“If your data systems and frameworks don’t succeed, AI won’t fail quietly — it will fail loudly.”**

And that’s exactly what we’ve seen across enterprise and startup implementations. Teams rush to ship agents, copilots, RAG systems, and LLM-powered workflows—but the data foundation underneath is brittle, incomplete, inconsistent, and ungoverned. And that becomes a death sentence for any LLM or agentic AI implementation.

After working through dozens of implementations, Ratnesh broke the core of the problem down into **7 non-negotiable data readiness checks** — all observed firsthand in real pipelines where skipping even one led to broken pipelines, corrupted embeddings, unusable recommendations, compliance issues, or multi-million-dollar rework.

**“When I was constructing my whole experiences with AI and the data pipelines I kind of converted into the seven pointers… this is the seven-pointer checklist whether your system or your data warehouse or your data pipeline is ready for the AI or not.”**

And he’s right.

And the timing couldn’t be more critical.

## Why these 7 data readiness checks matter now

Deep learning gave us powerful models… but GenAI changed the rules entirely.

As Ratnesh put it:

**“What we should be prepared as data engineers or data architects is — we need to make sure we follow these trends, we follow these tools, we keep on building these systems, start learning things.”**

The next wave of AI winners won’t be determined by who fine-tunes better or who uses the latest model. It’ll be determined by:

If you want AI-native products — copilots, personalized agents, automated workflows, AI-powered search — you need a data architecture that can feed an LLM the **right information, at the right time, with the right context, and in the right format.**

This is where his 7-point checklist to assess data infrastructure comes in, and why it matters now more than ever.

## 7-point checklist for AI-ready data

### 1️⃣ Unification- Is your data centralized and accessible through single connection?

Most AI projects die at the first step: connecting to data. Research and surveys consistently highlight data access and preparation as the most time-consuming and challenging aspects of an AI/ML project lifecycle.

Startups and enterprises alike store data across:

This fragmentation kills AI initiatives.

**“The first readiness check is simple: can your team access all critical data through a single unified access point?” — Ratnesh**

#### *Why it matters*

If your AI app needs inventory, order history, vendor profiles, user behavior, and reviews, but each lives in a different place, your LLM:

#### *Quick test*

If your backend dev asks, *“Where do I hit for this data?”* and you can’t answer in 10 seconds, you already failed Check #1.

### 2️⃣ Discoverability- Can your team find data without directly accessing it?

This is one of the most underestimated issues. Industry consensus supports this; the time spent by data professionals searching for and understanding existing data is substantial. This friction severely slows down AI development cycles.

Teams spend hours reverse-engineering naming conventions, schema mismatches, undocumented tables, and old ETL jobs.

AI makes this dramatically worse because:

**“People should be able to discover your data without opening the tables. If they need to inspect raw data to understand structure, you’re not AI-ready.” — Ratnesh**

Discoverability requires:

Without this layer, every AI project becomes guesswork.

![](https://www.talentica.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/unification.webp)

### 3️⃣ Quality & reliability- Whether the quality and reliability checkpoint has been implemented in the place?

This is where most hallucinations originate—not from the LLM, but from bad data feeding it.

Ratnesh says it plainly:

**“If your data is not trustworthy, your model becomes more dangerous, not more intelligent.”**

LLMs are nondeterministic. They amplify whatever you give them—clean or dirty.

You need:

**“Quality checkpoints must be implicit and by design—not ad-hoc fixes welded into your pipeline.”**

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

Data lakes (especially Delta Lakes with DBT) help enforce these constraints automatically—immutability, versioning, lineage, and enforced schema evolution.

If you’re still using an old warehouse without governance, you’re introducing hallucinations long before the LLM is even called.

### 4️⃣ Real-time access: Can your systems serve live data to LLMs & agents?

You can’t build modern AI experiences (support copilots, fraud detection, personalization, or decision intelligence) on stale data. AI applications like fraud detection, personalized recommendations, and live customer support agents require the most current context to make accurate and relevant decisions.

Relying on data that is hours or days old (typical of traditional batch ETL processes) severely limits the effectiveness and relevance of these AI systems.

Ratnesh’s e-commerce case study makes this brutally clear.

The client wanted:

But the system only had batch ETL, outdated data catalogs, and fragmented stores.

**“If your bots or AI agents cannot fetch real-time context, you will always land in the hallucination zone.” — Ratnesh**

### **Ask yourself**

Can your LLM retrieve:

If the answer is no, your AI feature will behave like a clueless intern who’s always one day behind.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

### 5️⃣ Trustworthiness- Is your data credible and complete enough to generate reliable AI outputs?

Trustworthiness goes beyond “quality.”

It asks:

**“If your data gives mixed signals, the LLM will hallucinate. It’s not the model. It’s your inconsistency.” — Ratnesh**

An LLM cannot discern which of two conflicting data sources is correct; it will simply blend or choose one, often producing a “mixed signal” output.

In the e-commerce case:

One missing trust layer, and the AI support assistant started giving wrong advice.

AI is a multiplier. If your raw material is flawed, AI magnifies the flaw.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

### 6️⃣ Scalability & cost awareness- Are you prepared for LLM-heavy workloads?

Many teams underestimate the cost side of AI.  Initial proof-of-concepts often use readily available cloud resources, but scaling these to production-level usage reveals significant recurring costs associated with computation (GPU usage for inference/training), vector search, and data processing.

RAG pipelines, embeddings, vector search, streaming updates—all come with recurring costs.

**“If you’re building on top of premium LLMs, you’re offering a premium product. The question is: will users pay for it?”**

If the answer is no, you must rethink:

Because using expensive, high-end commercial LLMs (like OpenAI’s GPT-4 or Anthropic’s Claude 3 Opus) incurs per-token costs that can quickly become economically unviable for standard enterprise applications where the user value doesn’t justify the operational expense.

Ratnesh is blunt about this:

**“If you want a normal enterprise application, but you use premium AI patterns, you’ll burn cash unnecessarily.”**

Scalability isn’t just about infra. It’s about economic sustainability.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

### 7️⃣ Contextualization- Does your data encode the rich context AI needs?

This is the *silent killer* of most AI deployments.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

Most companies have no consistent structure for:

Data for a “product” might exist in an inventory system, a sales log, and a support database, but without a shared, consistent structure, the AI cannot link these pieces together into a single, rich understanding.

In the e-commerce example, wrong or missing context caused:

LLMs rely heavily on the context provided in their input window to generate meaningful responses. Without context, an LLM might misinterpret a sales spike as fraud or a positive trend, leading to poor decisions. It cannot discern the nuance or intent behind the raw data.

Ratnesh puts it clearly:

**“If your system isn’t built to preserve context, everything looks like a vague text blob to an LLM.”**

Let’s take another case study

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB3aWR0aD0iMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIxIiB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciPjwvc3ZnPg==)

LLMs need context-rich data to chunk, embed, rank, and answer accurately.

Without it, your AI behaves randomly—sometimes correct, often confidently wrong.

Contextualization is a non-negotiable requirement for moving AI from experimental pilots to reliable, production-grade applications.

## How modern data lakes solve many of these problems automatically

Modern Delta Lakes (combined with DBT and strong governance) embed best practices into the system:

### **✔️ Immutability**

Prevents accidental overwrites and duplication.

### **✔️ Automatic schema enforcement**

Prevents broken pipelines.

### **✔️ Versioned data**

Enables rollback and auditability.

### **✔️ Built-in quality rules**

Eliminates manual fixes.

### **✔️ Cataloging + lineage**

Drives discoverability.

### **✔️ Uniform layers (raw → curated → semantic)**

Provides a clean path for embedding generation.

**“The quality of embeddings, the accuracy of chunking, and the consistency of semantics — all depend on how clean your lakehouse foundation is.”**

This is why Ratnesh recommends embedding generation *on curated semantic layers*, not raw stores or old warehouses.

### Why most companies skip these 7 checks

Because they assume AI sits “on top” of the product.

It doesn’t.

LLMs, agents, copilots, and RAG pipelines rely heavily on:

AI is not a feature — **it’s an architectural shift.**

**“To build systems that are first-time-right, the foundation must be first-right by design.” — Ratnesh**

## Your AI can only be as good as your data

If you skip these seven readiness checks, you’re not just slowing down innovation — you’re sabotaging your AI stack.

Here’s the uncomfortable reality:

Companies that succeed with AI don’t start with the model. They start with the **data foundation**.

## Conclusion

Before you build your next AI feature, ask: Is my data truly AI-ready? Or am I hoping the model will compensate for the gaps?

As Ratnesh aptly puts it:

*“AI will not fix bad data. It amplifies it. If you get your seven checks right, most of your AI challenges disappear before they even show up.”*

A reliable AI foundation requires reliable data engineering. We provide the foundational engineering expertise to build a clean, curated data layer. This ensures that when you move to embedding generation and complex AI features, you are building on a reliable foundation, not amplifying existing errors.

**Ensure Your Data Is AI-Ready. Partner with Talentica.**

**Take the first step toward a robust, AI-native future.**

[**Talk to Our AI-Native Engineers**](https://www.talentica.com/ai-development-services/)

Let’s Connect and build AI that ships, reliably.

# Data Readiness for AI Explained

* [Report this article](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fdata-readiness-ai-explained-kash-mehdi-rwzie&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=PONCHO_ARTICLE&_f=guest-reporting)

[Kash Mehdi](https://www.linkedin.com/in/kashmehdi) 

### Kash Mehdi

Published Dec 14, 2025

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Fdata-readiness-ai-explained-kash-mehdi-rwzie&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

## Introduction

AI is changing the status quo across nearly everything we have known. Its benefits are broad and apply to technology, information science, medical science, security, and consumer privacy. The impact of AI is already visible across industries. In automotive through self driving vehicles. In retail where AI drives supply chain automation and customer sentiment analysis to improve experience. In medical science through diagnostics and early disease detection such as cancer. These examples only scratch the surface.

While AI presents unprecedented opportunities for growth and innovation to address human needs, it also raises fundamental questions around morals, ethics, and ethos. Much of today’s organizational focus is on delivering AI powered products to meet consumer demand. However, there is a growing need to address AI explainability to govern how AI is built, operated, and deployed. This is critical to building consumer trust. AI safety and literacy also require greater attention, as not all workers and everyday users fully understand AI’s capabilities, limitations, or risks.

The conversation should not only be about what AI can do, but how AI should be developed, governed, and used to serve the basic needs of consumers responsibly.

The promise of AI is here, but unlocking its full value requires companies to get their data in order. AI depends on strong data foundations. Data leaders today face the challenge of balancing data infrastructure, architecture, workforce literacy, and governance. As data volumes are expected to double or triple every 12 to 18 months, much of this data remains untapped. Research shows that nearly two thirds of data stored in cloud environments is underutilized, limiting the true potential of AI.

To truly innovate with AI, many factors exist both within and outside the control of data and technology leaders. Data architectures often become siloed when they are not designed with a clear end goal. Conversations with leaders across industries reveal a common pattern. Organizations struggle with data accessibility and usability, leaving users unable to fully benefit from the data available to them. The last edition of Data Stash by Kash, "[Data Actors: Zombies in the Enterprise](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/data-actors-zombies-enterprise-kash-mehdi-ij4ee/?trackingId=qjOIEVlfR56mzCsmPe4g%2FQ%3D%3D&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block)" unpacks a list of challenges faced by different data actors and remains a core barrier to realizing AI driven value.

## Examples from the Hedge Fund Industry

Take quantitative finance as an example, where trusted data is a critical factor in AI development for hedge funds. Data is a core operational asset. Every data point can move millions, and given the highly regulated nature of the industry, every AI driven decision must be reproducible and explainable.

Many hedge funds today focus on building the best prediction engines to deliver strong investment strategies for shareholders. These strategies are shaped by internal research and development platforms where AI sits at the center of decision making and strategy construction. To provide context, a common practice across hedge funds is the large scale acquisition of financial data from providers such as Bloomberg, Aladdin, S&P Capital, and others. This data often arrives in a raw, fragmented, and inconsistent state.

Without strong data governance, organizations quickly develop silos. Data teams become disconnected, definitions vary, and data quality suffers. Even with modern data lakes or warehouses in place, the underlying data often remains messy and difficult to use. As a result, many hedge funds are recognizing the need for a more distributed operating model. This approach empowers data teams closest to the data and its signals, while assigning clear ownership to ensure consistency, trust, and accountability.

### Focus Area for Data & AI Leaders in Hedge Fund

The impact data and AI leaders can have in the hedge fund industry is significant. Feature engineering functions, in particular, operate within highly complex data ecosystems where understanding data relationships is essential. In the absence of governance, data is scattered across architectures, and teams lack a centralized way to understand how signals derived from raw data connect, how features are constructed, and how business context influences AI driven predictions.

### At the core of feature engineering, three key elements exist

1. Features are specific data points or transformations derived from raw data. They are curated and combined to feed predictive models and improve accuracy and relevance.
2. Bundles are collections of related features that support specific analytical use cases. They group financial and economic signals that serve as inputs for model training and research workflows.
3. Models consume these features to predict market behavior, optimize portfolios, and identify investment opportunities. Each model is tailored to a defined set of prediction or analysis tasks.

### Data Actors and their needs

In this context, a quant researcher must understand which features are consumed by which models and what data feeds each feature. This becomes increasingly difficult when data relationships are unclear and researchers face millions of potential data points without knowing which ones can be trusted.

Aligning data and AI decisions with business value is critical. These decisions directly impact core objectives such as managing systematic investment strategies, building high performance research and development platforms, and improving AI performance through better collaboration between researchers and engineers.

For hedge funds, data governance enables the design of self service environments that map features, bundles, and models using product management principles. Data and AI products are intentionally designed to solve specific business problems for defined users, with clear processes for discovery, usage, and accountability.

A strong governance program delivers a fully governed data and AI architecture that supports data engineers, ML and AI engineers, quant researchers, trading operators, and portfolio managers.

### Lessons Learned

Several lessons emerge that can be applied across industries beyond hedge funds.

1. Governance cannot be an afterthought. It must be embedded directly into data and feature production.
2. Feature ownership and quality standards should be clearly defined through metadata, validation rules, update frequency, and statistical thresholds.
3. Finally, feedback loops are essential. Automated monitoring of features and models allows teams to measure performance impact and continuously improve outcomes.

# The big leap: Getting data AI-ready

5 minute read   15 Oct 2024

Related topics 

[Technology leader's agenda](/en_us/cio)

[AI](/en_us/services/ai)

[Consulting](/en_us/services/ai)

[Emerging technology](/en_us/services/ai)

* [Facebook](# "Facebook")
* [Twitter](# "Twitter")
* [LinkedIn](# "LinkedIn")
* Link Copied

#### The rise of generative AI challenges organizations to enhance data strategies and governance to harness its transformative potential.

---

##### ****In brief****

* AI adoption is widespread across industries, yet data infrastructure challenges persist.
* Proper data management and governance are critical for leveraging AI's competitive advantage.
* EY survey highlights AI's efficiency benefits, but underscores the need for improved data readiness.

---

The meteoric rise of generative AI (GenAI) has given organizations of all sizes, across virtually every industry, a taste of what’s possible with evolving AI technologies. Yet, while the floodgates of innovation and opportunity have opened, [chief information officers (CIOs)](/en_us/cio) and their C-suite colleagues may find that their companies are ill-equipped to capitalize on AI because of long-standing limitations with their data programs and infrastructure.

How EY can help

* [Artificial Intelligence Consulting Services](/en_us/services/consulting/artificial-intelligence-consulting-services)

  Our Consulting approach to the adoption of AI and intelligent automation is human-centered, pragmatic, outcomes-focused and ethical.

   [Read more](/en_us/services/consulting/artificial-intelligence-consulting-services)

An [EY online survey](/en_us/consulting/businesses-can-stop-rising-ai-use-from-fueling-anxiety) revealed that 90% of respondents who work a desk/office job and are at least somewhat familiar with AI say that their organization uses at least one AI technology, with GenAI topping the list. Most say that using AI at work will make them more efficient (82%) and more productive (81%), and will let them focus on higher-value work (81%).

 

GenAI, in particular, has taken off in areas such as marketing, content management, contract management and the call center. This is on top of applied AI applications that are used to generate predictive insights that lead to more intelligent decision-making.

 

The survey found that, despite the mounting enthusiasm for these and myriad other use cases, there is anxiety about AI, including legal risks (69%), ethical and moral considerations (67%) and cybersecurity risks (67%). The data being used to fuel AI models is also under scrutiny. Almost half (48%) of respondents to the 2023 Foundry AI Priorities Study said that data quality and quantity issues could impede genAI implementations. They’re also concerned about data privacy and ethical considerations (41%), data variability (37%), and unlabeled or weakly labeled data (29%).

 

As [organizations prepare to leverage AI](/en_us/services/consulting/artificial-intelligence-consulting-services) for competitive advantage, many lack a robust foundation that primes their data for effective AI use at scale. These foundational components include data management and governance practices, AI governance and mature platforms for operationalizing the technology.

 

“AI needs management and governance to ensure ethical, security, economic and legal concerns are addressed, and associated risks are mitigated,” says [Zakir Hussain](/en_us/people/profile-blueprint.people.html/content/dam/content-fragments/ey-unified-site/ey-com/people/global/en/zakir-hussain), EY Americas Data Leader. “All of those need to be understood, planned for, and managed, and many companies are just not ready.”

 

## Getting your data ready for AI

Where do most companies fall short in pursuit of [**AI-ready data**](/en_us/services/emerging-technologies/knowledge-assets-enable-ai-to-make-informed-decisions)? Maturity levels vary, but most enterprises are lacking in one or more areas of data management, leading to an abundance of proof-of-concept (POC) project failures, Hussain says.

 

Data that is truly optimized for AI has four key characteristics, he explains:

* The data is reliable.
* It’s **[accessible and scalable](/en_us/insights/emerging-technologies/learn-how-leaders-deployed-generative-ai-for-employees)**.
* It’s visible with the proper context and consistency.
* It’s trusted and secure.

To get there, organizations need the following technology and process pillars in place:

* An AI-ready data strategy that is focused on [**business value drivers**](/en_us/services/emerging-technologies/six-pillars-of-ai-success-for-the-c-suite)
* Data governance for data consumers to explore, discover and use data sources efficiently
* Master data management for a single source of truth
* A risk and compliance framework for properly managed risks and access controls
* Data quality and data wrangling capabilities to ensure solutions with curated and validated data
* A robust data architecture for rapidly piloting and scaling solutions

“All of these elements determine whether data is ready for AI or not,” Hussain says. “If data isn’t contextualized, tagged or mastered properly, or if data lineage is broken, it’s bound to generate wrong predictions and drive the wrong decisions.”

 

Beyond investment in the right technology and data architecture, CIOs can foster data centricity and more mature practices by shifting data and analytics projects and culture toward a product management mindset. The traditional approach of data councils and enterprise data governance has moved the needle on establishing common taxonomies, developing shared data policies and curating multiple data sources. Yet, those practices often don’t go far enough to change culture or solve systematic data problems. Revamping organizational structure to establish product owners, creating practices for managing data throughout its entire lifecycle, and building teams that are focused on outcomes and results will go a long way in creating AI-ready data while increasing demand and funding for data and analytics initiatives.

 

## 4 steps to better data management

We offer a number of other recommendations that are designed to promote AI-ready data and data management practices:

**Develop a proper roadmap:** No data or AI initiative will succeed on its own without a formal business case and an intentional set of business outcomes. CIOs and data leaders need to thoroughly examine the value drivers for their individual organizations and formulate a data and AI roadmap that is aligned to those specific business goals and in cooperation with their business partners.

**Place relentless focus on value:**Too many AI and data-driven pilot projects fail because they’re too narrow or not tied to a specific business outcome. As opposed to doing a POC with a small data set just to establish relevancy and demonstrate success, Hussain advises CIOs to conduct pilot projects with real data that addresses a high-priority business problem or opportunity. “Stay focused on results and build a pipeline of use cases that are very results-oriented,” he says. “That will pave the way for the company to mature their data readiness.”

**Leverage AI (including GenAI) for efficiencies:**GenAI can play a role in [**streamlining data management and data quality practices.**](/en_us/services/emerging-technologies/choosing-genai-for-business-efficiency-over-complexity) For example, it can help to automate data quality checks, bring greater intelligence to master data management and help ensure dynamic data governance policies. “Things are changing so fast – you can’t set a governance policy and let it sit there for the next few years,” Hussain says. “Using GenAI to set up dynamic data policies allows systems and organizations to adapt and evolve policies.”

**Move quickly, but prepare for a marathon:**As AI looms large, business leaders are hankering to move fast. However, being too aggressive can result in data management missteps that slow down progress. It’s critical to develop a holistic strategy to modernize and ensure AI-ready data. “This is not a sprint,” Hussain says. “Data modernization needs to be carefully thought out, and you have to build a holistic strategy focused on business value drivers, and that’s not just about technology.”

Ernst & Young LLP (EY US) commissioned a third-party vendor to conduct the AI Anxiety in Business Survey. The online survey was performed among 1,000 Americans who work an office/desk job, either full- or part-time, and are at least somewhat familiar with AI. The survey was conducted from October 5-16, 2023. The margin of error for the total sample is +/- 3 percentage points.  
 *The views expressed by the author are not necessarily those of Ernst & Young LLP or other members of the global EY organization.*  
   
 Foundry, “Foundry’s Inaugural AI Priorities Study Examines Utilization of Artificial Intelligence in Organizations”, October 10, 2023.

#### Summary

The rise of generative AI, or GenAI, has shown organizations the potential of AI technologies. Yet, many companies cannot fully leverage AI due to limitations in their data programs. An EY survey reveals that while 90% of respondents use AI, 48% worry that data quality and quantity issues could hinder GenAI's effective implementation.

results.title: Vendasta Unveils Custom AI Employees to Redefine the Future of Work for Small Businesses Everywhere - Markets Financial Content
results.content: # Vendasta Unveils Custom AI Employees to Redefine the Future of Work for Small Businesses Everywhere. Saskatoon (Canada), Dec. 16, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Vendasta today announced the launch of Custom AI Employees, a groundbreaking capability that brings enterprise-grade automation to small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs). These AI agents are built on Vendasta’s unified platform and trained on the unique workflows, rules, and customer data of each business. How Custom AI Employees Fit into Real Business Workflows. In the coming months, Vendasta plans to expand the AI workforce with additional out-of-the-box AI Employees for common roles—such as managing business reputation, supporting sales operations, and delivering deeper analytical insights—while continuing to give businesses the flexibility to build fully custom AI Employees for their unique needs. Businesses and partners can start creating their first Custom AI Employee today at https://www.vendasta.com/ai-workforce/. Vendasta provides AI employees that help businesses attract, engage, and retain customers. * Vendasta Unveils Custom AI Employees.

results.title: Small Business Technology News This Week: Google Says Chatbots Are 69% Accurate - Forbes
results.content: Small Business Technology News #1 – Google finds AI chatbots are only 69% accurate...at best. Small Business Technology News #2 – CEOs to keep spending on AI, despite spotty returns. Small Business Technology News #3 – Meta considering charging business pages to post links. For businesses and marketers, here’s some useful information to keep in mind – according to Meta’s “Widely Viewed Content Report” published last week, Facebook posts that include a link get little traction in the app. Small Business Technology News #4 – Refer a friend app: New app pays people for recommending their favorite businesses to others. **Small Business Technology News #5**–**Zoom launches AI companion 3.0 with agentic workflows, transforming conversations into action.**. Zoom combines its own language models with top third-party ones (e.g., OpenAI, Anthropic, and open-source models like NVIDIA Nemotron) to deliver smarter, more flexible responses in what Zoom calls a “federated approach.” The new AI Companion’s features include Agentic Retrieval capabilities that locates information across meeting summaries, transcripts and notes; a Post Meeting Follow Up prompt generates follow-up tasks and messages; and Agentic Writing mode helps draft, edit and refine business documents based on specific meetings or resources.

results.title: AI is here – but first you need to get your data in order - The Manufacturer
results.content: # AI is here – but first you need to get your data in order. As adoption accelerates across businesses of all sizes, success will depend not on technology alone, but on high-quality data, strong governance and human oversight to ensure AI delivers real commercial value rather than costly mistakes. For manufacturers who have already become more data-driven, AI is the next step in their journey, a way to get more value from their data, rapidly and at scale. The starting point for any AI project must be good quality data. Well-governed, company-approved AI tools, delivered by an expert vendor and powered by reliable data, also reduces the chance that people will use other AI applications in a potentially risky way. You first need to identify the areas where AI could deliver the most value to your business and then map out what data you need to achieve it. Approved AI tools, powered by high-quality data, can help to future-proof your business, giving you the confidence to innovate and scale.

output:
## Custom AI Workforce

For small-business leaders navigating today's competitive landscape, the concept of a custom AI workforce is emerging as a powerful solution to perennial challenges like staff shortages and rising customer expectations [1]. This innovative approach brings enterprise-grade automation within reach of small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs), allowing them to deploy specialized AI agents tailored to their unique operational needs [1, 2].

Unlike generic AI tools, a custom AI employee is an intelligent agent built and trained on a business's specific workflows, rules, internal documents, and customer data [1, 3]. This deep integration enables the AI to perform real work that aligns precisely with a company's established processes, rather than just offering general assistance [3]. Businesses define the role, train the AI using their existing knowledge and procedures, and then deploy it where needed, often with no-code setup required [1, 3].

The benefits for SMBs are significant, including standardizing key workflows, enhancing customer touchpoints, and unlocking new levels of productivity without needing to expand headcount [1, 2]. These custom AI agents can connect to existing business systems via APIs, allowing them to take practical actions beyond simple chat. This means they can check inventory, create CRM records, schedule appointments, or manage billing follow-ups, operating consistently across various channels such as website chat, internal team communication, and automated workflows [3].

Real-world applications highlight the transformative potential. For instance, at Blue River Digital, a custom AI employee named "Banks" revolutionized their sales process by generating six proposals in minutes instead of hours, ensuring accuracy and consistency. This allowed the team to scale operations more efficiently without adding staff [1, 3]. Similarly, The Xcite Group leveraged their custom AI, "Klaygent," to train on years of internal advertising data, enabling every team member to provide instant, expert-level recommendations, improving sales effectiveness and customer experience [1, 3]. Beyond these, custom AI can handle a wide array of high-volume tasks like quoting, project updates, internal knowledge support, and customer communications [3].

This tailored integration of AI stands in contrast to the historical trend where the biggest gains from generative AI often favored larger organizations with deep integration capabilities [1]. By focusing on practical, workflow-ready AI, SMBs can now equip their human teams to be more productive. As the AI landscape evolves, the focus shifts from replacing workers to augmenting them, empowering a "centaur" workforce (human + AI) that drives greater value [5]. The future envisions an expansion of these AI workforces, with more pre-configured options for common roles like reputation management and sales operations, alongside the ongoing flexibility for businesses to build fully custom AI solutions [1, 2]. This marks the dawn of a truly AI-powered local economy, addressing chronic staff shortages with intelligent, scalable solutions [1].

---
Sources:
[1] Vendasta Unveils Custom AI Employees to Redefine the Future of... — vendasta.com
[2] Vendasta Unveils Custom AI Employees to Redefine the Future of... — finance.yahoo.com
[3] Custom AI Employees - Vendasta — vendasta.com
[4] Custom AI Solutions - Turbine Workforce — turbineworkforce.com
[5] AI Revolution 2025: Building the Future Workforce Today — baytechconsulting.com

## AI Tool Accuracy & Use

As AI tools become increasingly integrated into daily operations, small-business leaders must approach their implementation with a clear understanding of their inherent limitations, particularly regarding accuracy. Even the most advanced AI models are not infallible; for instance, the top-performing Gemini 3 Pro model achieves only 68.8% overall factual accuracy, meaning it gets facts wrong roughly one-third of the time [1]. This underscores the critical need for human oversight and verification of AI-generated content.

The reliability challenges extend to tools designed to detect AI-generated content. A multitude of AI detectors exist, claiming to identify text and images produced by large language models like GPT [2]. However, multiple studies indicate these detectors are "neither accurate nor reliable," frequently generating high rates of both false positives and false negatives [5, 2]. False positives incorrectly flag human-written content as AI-generated, which can lead to significant issues, particularly given that these tools are prone to flagging non-native English speakers or neurodivergent writers at higher rates due to their writing styles [5]. Conversely, false negatives occur when AI-generated text goes undetected. Users can often circumvent these detectors through simple evasive techniques, such as paraphrasing, adding emotional elements, or using specialized "humanizer" AI tools [5]. This creates an "eternal arms race" where generators and detectors constantly evolve, with no definitive solution in sight [5].

Given these detection challenges and the inherent inaccuracies of generative AI, the imperative for human vetting is paramount. Small-business leaders and their teams must develop strong critical thinking skills to evaluate AI-generated output. Before using any AI output, it is essential to check its accuracy, verify facts, and assess for potential biases, as AI models are trained on internet content that can contain misinformation or reflect existing biases [3]. The responsibility ultimately falls on the user to ensure the information is correct and appropriate for its intended purpose [3].

To truly gauge the value of AI in decision-making, it's crucial to move beyond simple accuracy assessments to a more comprehensive evaluation framework. Five key metrics can help measure the real-world impact of AI-generated answers on organizational decisions: accuracy, relevance, coherence, helpfulness, and user trust [4]. Accuracy confirms factual correctness against authoritative sources; relevance ensures the response directly addresses user intent within the specific business context; coherence assesses the logical structure and clarity of the information; helpfulness measures whether the AI output actually enables users to accomplish their goals and make better decisions; and user trust reflects the overall confidence employees have in the AI system based on consistent positive experiences [4]. By focusing on these broader metrics, small businesses can effectively evaluate if AI tools are genuinely enhancing productivity and driving better outcomes, rather than just delivering information.

### Sources

[1] Google's New Benchmark Reveals Wide Gaps in AI Factual Accuracy — hackshackers.com
[2] Artificial Intelligence Tools for Detection, Research and Writing — guides.library.ttu.edu
[3] Dos and Don'ts of AI - Artificial Intelligence for Students — ulm.libguides.com
[4] 5 metrics to measure AI-generated answers' decision-making impact — glean.com
[5] False Positives and False Negatives - Generative AI Detection Tools — lawlibguides.sandiego.edu

## Data Readiness for AI

The allure of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for boosting efficiency, gaining insights, and transforming operations is undeniable for small-business leaders. However, effectively harnessing AI's power hinges on a foundational, often overlooked, element: data readiness [1, 5]. Many organizations are enthusiastic, with 94% increasing spending on AI data readiness, yet only 21% have successfully integrated AI into their operations [1]. Without a robust data strategy, AI initiatives risk failure, with Gartner estimating that 60% of AI projects built on unready data will be abandoned by 2026 [3].

The core principle is simple: "garbage in, garbage out" [1]. If the data used to train AI models is biased, incomplete, outdated, or inconsistent, the AI's outputs will reflect these flaws. This is especially true for unstructured data—emails, documents, images, and videos—which constitutes 80-90% of enterprise data and is crucial for advanced AI innovation [1]. Dispersed across silos, difficult to access, and often lacking proper management, this vast dataset holds immense potential if properly prepared [1].

Achieving AI-ready data requires a strategic approach focusing on several key pillars:

1.  **Quality and Trustworthiness:** Data must be complete, correct, consistent, and free of bias to generate reliable AI outputs [1, 3, 5]. Quality checkpoints need to be embedded by design, not as afterthoughts, to prevent AI from amplifying flaws and leading to "hallucinations" or incorrect decisions [3]. For instance, in finance, trusted data is critical because every AI-driven decision must be reproducible and explainable [4].

2.  **Unification and Accessibility:** AI applications demand access to all critical data through a single, unified point [3]. Data fragmented across various systems (databases, cloud storage, spreadsheets) makes it challenging for AI models to connect disparate pieces of information, hindering comprehensive insights [3]. This also includes ensuring data is stored in the right place for the right workload, whether on-premise, in the cloud, or at the edge [1].

3.  **Governance and Discoverability:** Strong data governance is paramount for managing data throughout its lifecycle, ensuring visibility, security, and compliance [1, 4, 5]. This means clear ownership, consistent metadata, documented data lineage, and a framework for risk and access controls [3, 4, 5]. Data should be discoverable without needing direct access to tables, requiring robust cataloging and standardized definitions to speed up AI development [3].

4.  **Real-time Access and Contextualization:** Modern AI applications, such as personalized recommendations or fraud detection, require real-time data to make accurate decisions [3]. Stale data significantly limits effectiveness [3]. Moreover, data needs rich context to be meaningful to AI, including relationships, intent, and relevance [3]. Without proper contextualization, AI struggles to link information, leading to vague or inaccurate responses [3].

5.  **Scalability and Cost Awareness:** AI workloads can be resource-intensive, incurring significant recurring costs for computation and data processing [3]. An AI-ready data infrastructure must consider the economic sustainability of scaling AI solutions, optimizing for efficiency without compromising performance [3].

Interestingly, AI isn't just a consumer of ready data; it can actively enhance data management in a mutually beneficial cycle [2]. AI capabilities can automate data discovery, enrich metadata, detect anomalies in real-time, and monitor for policy violations, improving overall data quality and governance [2]. This symbiotic relationship suggests that data readiness is not a one-off hurdle, but a continuous process that AI itself can accelerate [2].

Ultimately, data readiness is an ongoing journey and an architectural shift, not a single project [1, 3]. Organizations that commit to building and maintaining strong data foundations will be better positioned to unlock AI's full value, foster long-term relationships with customers through enhanced services, and lead the next wave of innovation [1].

---

**Sources**
[1] How to sell: Data readiness for AI — Computerweekly (computerweekly.com)
[2] Data Management & AI: The Two-Way Street of Data Readiness — Forvis Mazars (forvismazars.us)
[3] 7 Data Readiness Checks You're Probably Skipping — But Your AI... — Talentica (talentica.com)
[4] Data Readiness for AI Explained — LinkedIn (linkedin.com)
[5] The big leap: Getting data AI-ready — EY - US (ey.com)
